questions.prompt: Which best describes your website/app tracking setup?

options.label: No tracking or basic Google Analytics only (default setup).
Standard tracking of pageviews and some events via GA or similar.
Detailed event tracking using GTM with documented custom events.
Comprehensive tracking via a CDP capturing key actions across platforms.
Unified tracking with server-side implementation handling cookie limitations.

questions.prompt: How do you manage analytics tags and pixels?

options.label: Tags are hard-coded directly into the site or managed ad‑hoc.
We use Google Tag Manager but without documented processes.
GTM with naming conventions and basic QA before publishing.
Formal tag governance with version control, testing, and approval workflows.
Automated tag auditing with real-time monitoring for data quality issues.

questions.prompt: What user behaviors are you tracking today?

options.label: Just page visits and transaction completions.
Core funnel events: product views, add-to-cart, checkout steps.
Full funnel plus engagement events (scroll depth, video plays, clicks).
All above plus user attributes and cross-device behavior.
Behavior + offline data (returns, support, in-store) unified into one view.

questions.prompt: Do you link data from different customer touchpoints?

options.label: No, data sits in each tool separately.
We manually combine some data (e.g., export CSVs into spreadsheets).
We automatically merge data from multiple sources on a schedule.
Unified customer profiles combining web, marketing, and CRM data.
Real-time single customer view with identity resolution across channels.

questions.prompt: How do you attribute sales to marketing efforts?

options.label: We look at platform-reported conversions in each tool separately.
We use GA4 or similar with default last-click attribution.
We use a rules-based multi-touch model (time-decay, position-based).
Data-driven attribution validated by incrementality experiments.
Unified measurement combining MTA, MMM, and ongoing calibration tests.

questions.prompt: Do you measure incremental lift of marketing vs. baseline?

options.label: No, we only look at attributed conversions.
We’ve done one-off tests in the past but not systematically.
Occasional holdout tests (1 to 2 per year).
Regular geo-lift or holdout experiments validate our attribution.
Always-on incrementality measurement informs major spend decisions.

questions.prompt: Can you track a single user's journey across channels?

options.label: No, each channel is analyzed separately.
Partially, we use UTMs and GA multi-channel funnels.
Mostly, we see paths in a funnel analysis but with gaps.
Yes, a multi-channel dashboard shows the journey end-to-end.
Full cross-device + cross-channel journey with deterministic/probabilistic matching.

questions.prompt: How do you decide budget allocation across channels?

options.label: Mostly fixed budgets or gut feeling.
Based on platform-reported ROAS per channel.
Based on blended CAC and custom attribution weights.
Using MMM/econometric models to forecast diminishing returns.
Automated optimization using predictive models with continuous feedback.

questions.prompt: How often do you produce analytical reports and how?

options.label: No regular reporting, only on request or for specific meetings.
Monthly/weekly KPI reports produced manually in spreadsheets.
Automated dashboards updated daily with weekly reviews.
Interactive BI dashboards with self-service for all teams.
Real-time monitoring with anomaly alerts and predictive insights.

questions.prompt: What do your analytics dashboards cover?

options.label: Basic web metrics or sales, isolated by channel.
Marketing metrics from multiple platforms in one view.
Unified business view: marketing, eComm, and finance metrics together.
Cohort analysis, funnel drop-offs, and marketing ROI in one place.
Cross-functional dashboards tying campaigns to revenue and ops metrics.

questions.prompt: Do teams have agreed-upon metrics and a single source of truth?

options.label: Each team uses their own metrics and tools.
We have a standard report but teams dispute the numbers.
Defined metric framework (CAC, LTV) but not always enforced.
Company-wide metrics with documented definitions; everyone uses the same dashboards.
Certified metrics with governance, semantic layer, and audit trails.

questions.prompt: How quickly can you identify and act on an anomaly?

options.label: Often find out long after the fact through ad-hoc checks.
Weekly reviews catch most issues within a week.
Daily dashboard checks enable same-day detection of major issues.
Automated alerts notify us within hours.
Real-time monitoring with auto-diagnosis and suggested actions.

questions.prompt: How frequently does your team run experiments (A/B tests)?

options.label: Never or almost never.
A few times a year on major changes.
Continuously in some areas (1 to 3 tests running at a time).
Core workflow, roadmap of experiments, 5 to 10 tests per month.
High-velocity culture, every initiative has a test; learnings catalogued.

questions.prompt: What tools or methods do you use to experiment?

options.label: None, changes are based on intuition or stakeholder requests.
Manual split tests; compare outcomes roughly.
Basic A/B testing tool for site or email.
Dedicated experimentation platform with statistical rigor.
Server-side tests + feature flags + bandits/advanced allocation.

questions.prompt: How do experimental results influence decisions?

options.label: We don't run experiments to influence decisions.
If a test shows lift we implement; otherwise ad-hoc.
Results are documented and shared; they inform future tactics.
Experiment database + meta-analysis informs strategy.
Experiment data feeds models for personalization and auto-optimization.

questions.prompt: Do you use advanced optimization beyond A/B tests?

options.label: No, just manual optimizations based on reports.
Basic personalization (e.g., name in emails, simple segments).
Rule-based personalization on site and in campaigns.
Predictive models for recommendations and next-best-action.
AI-driven personalization optimizing for each user in real-time.

questions.prompt: What metrics do you track beyond immediate conversion?

options.label: None besides sales and immediate revenue.
Repeat purchase rate or basic churn in a simple way.
Cohort retention metrics and estimated CLV for groups.
LTV by acquisition source + retention curves + predictive CLV.
Dynamic CLV models updated in real-time feeding decisions.

questions.prompt: How do you segment and target customers in marketing?

options.label: We don't segment; all customers get the same messages.
Basic segments in email (one-time vs repeat, simple demographics).
Lifecycle stages (new, active, at-risk, churned) with tailored campaigns.
RFM segmentation + predictive scoring drives multi-channel targeting.
1:1 personalization using ML models across touchpoints.

questions.prompt: Which retention tactics do you use informed by data?

options.label: None, primarily promotional batch sends to the full list.
Basic automations: welcome series, abandoned cart.
Behavioral triggers + targeted lapsing-customer campaigns.
Predictive churn models trigger proactive win-back offers.
Orchestrated journeys optimizing next-best-action across channels.

questions.prompt: Do lifecycle insights influence product or strategy?

options.label: We don't analyze lifecycle data for strategic decisions.
We look at some metrics like churn but not systematically.
Retention analysis informs specific initiatives (e.g., onboarding improvements).
Dedicated retention team uses data to continuously improve CX.
Customer intelligence is embedded in product and strategy decisions.

questions.prompt: How do you consolidate and store data for analysis?

options.label: Data only lives in source tools (no central database).
Export data into spreadsheets/Sheets when needed.
Basic warehouse/database with occasional manual imports.
Automated ETL pipeline feeding a cloud warehouse daily.
Modern data stack with streaming, transformations, and reverse ETL.

questions.prompt: Which data sources are integrated?

options.label: None, all separate in each SaaS tool.
Some marketing platforms integrated (e.g., GA + ads).
Key sources (Shopify, GA, ads, email) piped into one warehouse.
All critical sources including CRM, support, offline in unified schema.
Enterprise-grade integration with enrichment and minimal silos.

questions.prompt: Do you have processes to ensure data accuracy?

options.label: Missing/inconsistent data; no formal checks.
Manual cleaning and verification when issues surface.
Validation rules and monitoring for pipeline failures.
Quality framework with owners, SLAs, and automated tests.
DataOps: CI/CD for data, anomaly detection, data contracts.

questions.prompt: What advanced capabilities does your infrastructure support?

options.label: Basic reporting from source tools.
Some segmentation and historical trend analysis.
Complex queries, large-scale analysis, data modeling.
Near real-time analytics, feature store, activation workflows.
Full ML infrastructure: training, serving, monitoring in production.
